awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Strain localization, shear zone connectivity, and magma-deformation interactions by depth within a 65 km thick transpressional continental arc
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how large fault zones develop over time at different depths within the Earth's crust is vital to the goals of assessing earthquake and volcanic hazards and finding natural resources, including natural gas, petroleum, and water. Not only are fault zones the sites of concentrated movement and seismic activity; they also form conduits by which fluids, magmas, and heat circulate through the Earth. A major unsolved problem centers on how the behavior of near surface faults relates to deformation in the deepest parts of fault systems, including the lowermost crust and upper mantle. Two of the most challenging aspects of resolving this problem are (1) a high degree of variability in the physical properties and behavior of faults at great depths and (2) there are few places on Earth that expose large tracts of material that once resided at depths below approximately 40 km and are available for direct study. This project utilizes one of only a few places on the planet where it is possible to directly observe the deep roots of an ancient fault system that once penetrated continental crust to depths of more than 65 km. Deep within Fiordland National Park, in southwest New Zealand, a near vertical fault zone up to 20 km thick can be traced continuously from areas that once resided at depths of 10 km to depths of 65 km during the Cretaceous time period. The research team, in collaboration with New Zealand researchers, will determine the internal structure, mineralogy, and behavior of this ancient fault zone at different depths and will show how the fault zone connects vertically through the crust and helped move, fluids, magmas, and crustal melts from mantle depths to near-surface environments. These are fundamental issues that are important to the understanding of all large fault zones, including those that occur with the United States and elsewhere. The project will also advance desired societal outcomes through an innovative, summer workshop program that provides research experiences to underrepresented students at minority-serving institutions in southern California, thereby promoting interest in research and graduate school opportunities. Providing graduate and undergraduate students with international field experiences and exposure to cutting-edge analytical research facilities will develop a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

An unsolved problem in continental tectonics centers on how competing weakening mechanisms localize deformation into faults and shear zones deep within the roots of continental arcs. This problem is especially acute in Cordilleran systems where episodes of voluminous magmatism, crustal melting, and high-grade metamorphism quickly change the compositional and rheological structures of the deep crust. The aim of this project is to determine how strain localization was achieved and sustained within the deep root of an ancient Cordilleran arc located in Fiordland, New Zealand during a cycle of magmatism and transpression. The project integrates transect maps, U-Pb geo- and thermochronology (zircon, titanite), and electron backscatter diffraction analyses to determine the following: (1) how competing weakening mechanisms localized strain at lower and middle crustal depths with a large transpressional shear zone, (2) how high-strain zones connected vertically across deep crustal boundaries, and (3) how temporal and spatial variations in magmatic, metamorphic, and deformational processes influenced shear zone development. The outcomes of this project will include a new 4-D model that shows how high-strain zones at different depths are physically connected within Cordilleran arcs, how strain localization is achieved and sustained within them, and how the deformation interacts with migrating magma and melts. This project is important because large faults and shear zones play a key role in the formation and evolution of continental lithosphere. They act as agents of weakening and hardening at different depths and they advect mass and heat through the lithosphere. One of the most challenging aspects of studying these features is determining their variability throughout the crust and mantle. Physical experiments, numerical models, and studies of xenoliths help us infer how materials deform at great depths, but polyphase flow laws for lower crustal compositions are scarce and no experimental studies of anorthite-diopside aggregates yet include melt in the deformation. In addition, few places expose large tracts of material that once resided at depths below about 40 km. To address these problems, this project involves a field-based investigation of strain localization mechanisms within the world's largest and deepest (up to 65 km) known exposure of lower arc crust. The project will provide new information on the geometry, composition, thermal evolution, and rheology of lower crustal shear zones that once penetrated the crust to depths of at least 65 km.

The Tectonics Program (Div. of Earth Sciences) and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering are supporting this project.

por.por_cntn:
Faults and shear zones are regions of concentrated deformation, across which significant crustal displacements have accumulated.  These structures are important because they regulate the transfer of mass and heat below the Earth?s surface.  Their links to natural hazards (e.g., earthquakes) and natural resources (e.g., water and minerals) also make them important to human societies.  Two of the most challenging aspects of understanding these systems have been determining (1) how near-surface deformation in fault zones physically connects to deformation in the deep crust and upper mantle and (2) how these connections change over time.  These problems are difficult to solve because of the wide variety of styles and behaviors that operate on different time and length scales in fault systems. In addition, most areas of active faulting do not expose their deep roots and even fewer places allow scientists to directly observe how fault-related deformation is expressed at all levels of the crust within a single system. 

To solve these problems, we combined structural analyses with U-Pb zircon and titanite geochronology to determine how two large shear zone systems located in Fiordland, New Zealand initiated and grew over a 25 million year period. These shear zones are exposed within a tilted section of continental crust that represents Earth?s largest (~4500 km2) and deepest (to 65 km depth) known exposure of a continental magmatic arc.  The tilted section (Fig. 1a) allowed us to examine shear zone evolution and connectivity at all depths within the crust (Fig. 1b, 2).

The results show that an eastern, magma-poor shear zone system (Grebe-Indecision Creek shear zone) (Figs. 2, 3) formed first at ~136 Ma by reactivating a boundary that marks the old Paleozoic edge of Gondwana. In the upper crust (<15 km depth), the system is composed of moderately-dipping reverse faults that transition downward into a mesh-like network of steep, 1-2 km-wide shear zones in the middle crust (15-35 km depth) (Fig. 2).  The mid-crustal shear zones form a ~10 km-wide zone of transpression that coalesces downward into a steep, 4 km-wide zone of inclined, amphibolite-facies shear in the lower crust (35-55 km depth). The deformation initiated at or above ~20 km depth as an oblique-reverse fault that accommodated the partial subduction of an outboard part of the Median Batholith beneath Gondwana (Fig. 5, 6a). It then propagated downward at ~2-3 mm yr-1 reaching the base of the lower crust by ~124 Ma (Fig. 6b) and accumulating at least 30-45 km of horizontal (arc-normal) shortening, ~35 km of (NW over SE) vertical displacements, and ≤10 km of lateral displacements from 136 to 124 Ma.

A  western, magma-rich shear zone system (George Sound shear zone) (Fig. 2, 4, 5) nucleated at or near the base of the lower crust ( ~55 km depth) at ~124 Ma and propagated upward (Figs. 6c, 6d).  This system incorporated a flare-up in arc magmatism that peaked at 118-115 Ma when ~70% of the arc root was emplaced.  By ~120 Ma, the deformation had formed a steep, 12-km-wide shear zone inside a ~20 km-thick, partially molten, lower crustal pluton (the Western Worsley) that quickly (in ~3 m.y.) narrowed into a 1-2 km-wide, high-strain zone as the intrusion solidified (Fig. 6c, 6d).  Steep shear zone segments then propagated upward across other plutons at ~3 mm yr-1, reaching mid-crustal depths (30-25 km) by ~115 Ma and the upper crust (<15 km) after ~110 Ma.  When the high-strain zones entered the middle crust, the system widened by a factor of three as fold-thrust belts formed on either side of a steep, central shear zone. Detachment faults formed at the tops and bottoms of the solidifying plutons. At its shallowest levels, the system is marked by steep, narrow faults that offer no hint of the geometric complexity at depth.  

These results show that the primary driver of strain localization in both shear zone systems at all depths was the reactivation of two steep, inherited boundaries after magma infiltrated their roots.  In addition, the intrusion of plutons whose physical properties changed over time was the primary cause of geometric complexity, including how propagating shear zones interacted with compositional and rheological boundaries in the crust.

 

            This project contributed to MS theses at the University of Vermont (Eddy, Moyer, Lindquist, Lincoln) and the minority-serving California State University Northridge (Carty, Dietel, Page, Brown). It also supported two undergraduates (Lincoln, Lee) from underrepresented groups. It enhanced collaborations among U.S. and New Zealand scientists. Sample collections and data are archived at GNS Science (NZ) and shared in the PetLab database. Analytical facilities at UVM, CSUN, UCSB, and USGS-Stanford were supported.  Training and learning was enhanced by involving students in field trips, meetings, and publications. All publications include student authors.  Three journal articles and 14 abstracts have student first authors. Results were disseminated via publications, public forums, websites, classrooms and a video series.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2022
Modified by: Keith A Klepeis

Images (1 of )
  • (a) Map showing Cretaceous paleodepths and crustal divisions in Fiordland and Stewart Island. (b) Map showing Early Cretaceous high-strain zones at ~115 Ma.
    Klepeis et al., in review. �Submitted for publication in Tectonics.
    Public Domain
    Keith A Klepeis
    Fiordland Crustal Section
  • Reconstructed profiles through the Median Batholith showing high-strain zones by depth. A western shear zone system includes the George Sound (GS) and Straight River shear zones (GSSZ). An eastern system includes the Grebe and Indecision Creek shear zones (Grebe-IC), and the Freshwater fault.
    Klepeis et al., 2022, Submitted for publication in Tectonics.
    Copyrighted
    Keith A Klepeis
    Vertical cross sections
  • Map of N. Fiordland showing trends of inherited Paleozoic foliations, D1 and D2 fabric trajectories, and the western limit of exposed D2 deformation in the vicinity of the Grebe-IC shear zone.
    Klepeis et al., 2022, Submitted for publication in Tectonics.
    Copyrighted
    Keith A Klepeis
    Map of Eastern Shear Zone
  • Map showing the extent of D3 magmatism and subsequent (D4-D6) deformation stages in two major deep crustal shear zones. Thin dashed lines are fabric trajectories in the vicinity of the George Sound and Grebe-IC shear zones.
    Klepeis et al., 2022, Submitted for publication in Tectonics.
    Copyrighted
    Keith A Klepeis
    Map of simultaneous magmatism and deformation in deep crustal shear zones
  • Sketch summarizing the 3-D architecture of the Median Batholith�s middle and lower crust. Oblique underthrusting of the outboard arc beneath Gondwana occurred along the Grebe-Indecision Creek shear zone (ICSZ). Vertical variations in the age and style of plutons occur in the George Sound shear zone.
    Klepeis et al., 2022, Submitted for publication in Tectonics.
    Copyrighted
    Keith A Klepeis
    Block diagram of deep crustal magmatism and deformation
